headline.main: At Site of Quelled Prisoner Revolt, Afghan Fort's Walls Tell a Tale of Death

lead_paragraph: With the mud walls of this 19th-century fort shell-pocked and still smoldering from three days of battle, Northern Alliance soldiers today picked over the bodies of more than 150 Taliban prisoners -- many apparently Pakistanis, some Arabs -- who were killed in an uprising against their captors. As the Northern Alliance troops carried out the bodies of their own men, those of the Taliban prisoners lay where they fell, hit by gunfire on the open parade ground, blasted by American airstrikes or killed after being hunted down in the many hiding places in the stables and outbuildings.
abstract: Northern Alliance troops carry out bodies of own men from fortress in Qala Jangi, Afghanistan, site of quelled revolt by Taliban prisoners; bodies of some 150 prisoners, many apparently Pakistanis, some Arabs, lay where they fell; Red Cross has reportedly removed nearly 120 dead prisoners; some 400 prisoners were in fort when group of them, reportedly angered by presence of American interrogators, rushed guards; photos (M)
